utterance: "You are a lucky dog,"
speaker: associates

utterance: "All ashore,”
speaker: sailors

utterance:
"Tapnagle," said he, "the issue of every enterprise depends upon the handling of it.
If you are successful, the end will be accomplished not so much by what you believe, as what you make others believe. You need not be disappointed if those you try to influence are at first reluctant to accept your views, for what has developed through much pondering to a conviction in your mind, may as yet be only an idea in theirs. Take them along afoot for a time, and if your arguments are good, they will finally be willing to ride with you at a gallop. No man ever accomplished a great object without first preparing himself for the task. This is done by thoroughly saturating one's self with knowledge at the expense of ignorant conceit, the cultivation of patience at the expense of over-activity, reasonableness at the expense of petulance, and personal influence at the expense of austerity. And here let me remind you that personal influence is greatest when the ego is least, for when the ego is prominent one is catering to his own weakness, when he should be catering to the weaknesses of those he wishes to influence.
Personal influence based on knowledge always gives weight, while that based on conviviality gives lustre only, which in society goes farther than merit, but not so when dollars are involved. There goes the third bell. Good-bye, Tapnagle," said he, shaking my hand, "remember we have trusted a great enterprise to your judgment. Therefore, be frank and open with that judgment. Keep no secrets from it."
speaker: old man Fessenden

utterance: "Humph! if I am on a steamer steering out into the Atlantic, as I believe myself to be, and if I am endowed with powers of accurate perception, with which I have always been credited, and am free from the delusions of inebriety, and I can imagine no reason why I should not be, Coney Island must have imbibed some of the Spts. Frumenti, for the quantity of which, if not the quality, it is so justly famous, and has set out to beat us across the ocean."
speaker: narrator

utterance: "Mein young frient, ven you get olter, you vill fint dot dings are not alvays joost vot dey seem, for it depents on de point of view you look at 'em."
speaker: a short, squattybuilt, middle-aged man

utterance: "Point of view you look at them ?"
speaker: narrator

utterance:
"Haven't I been standing on this deck since Coney Island first appeared over the whaleback?
Then it appeared midship, and now, when we are supposedly running away from it, it's nearly over the duckback.”
speaker: narrator

utterance: "Dot's joost vy men are such vools, dey look at a ding vonct, und dey look at a ding twict, und dey dink it has moved ven it's joost de same; dey don't know dey have changed de point of observation. Dis ship is following de channel und steers at different points of de compass, und so you dink dat Coney Island is bobbing arount like a cork in a virlpool. Young man, you vant to learn to read your compass vot you sail droo life mit, und you vill find de vorld joost right."
speaker: a short, squattybuilt, middle-aged man

utterance: "What a stupid Dutchman,"
speaker: narrator

utterance: "stupid Dutchman,”
speaker: narrator

utterance: "I am glad to get out of that hole, I thought Chicago was the hottest place on earth, but New York can beat it."
speaker: a Chicagoan

utterance: "That may be, but it is not the only thing in which New York beats Chicago.'
speaker: narrator

utterance: "Eh!"
speaker: a Chicagoan

utterance: "Chicago is a great place. Great business done there. More pigs killed in Chicago every year than in all the rest of the world."
speaker: a Chicagoan

utterance: "Gentlemen, take my advice, Discuss the merits of your city, your horse or your yacht only in the festive atmosphere of the smoking-room. A good cigar tends to conviviality, and is soothing to the nerves. It assists an illogical mind to come to logical conclusions. It helps to replace unsound arguments with common sense, which is important in an argumentative conversation if good fellowship is to be maintained."
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance: "I maintain, that smokers should always get together, as there is one point upon which they can agree, which is not true of most congregations promiscuously assembled, and that is, there is nothing to equal a good cigar. If a man has not arrived at this stage of maturity, he is no smoker and needs to serve an apprenticeship."
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance:
"We appear to be the smokers of the ship, and as smokers are always congenial comrades, we may consider ourselves acquainted.
We need no formal introduction, as the cigar sets aside all rules of formality, but if we know something of one another, as for instance names and where each hails from, it will facilitate fellowship. My name is Sprocton and my home is New York. Now if others of you will give the company as much information, we will be on the high road to companionship."
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance:
"I am Dr. Hobbs from Texas; Pemberton Hobbs, M. D., Every one in Texas knows Dr. Hobbs. My name is a household word there, and I trust it is not unknown in other parts of the country, even in New York City.
I have investigated and solved many of the perplexing problems of my profession. I also pride myself on being a broad scholar. I am a scientist of no small repute. Politics is my hobby, and I enjoy a discussion on theology.
Gentlemen, you are fortunate. Your education will expand, your fund of general information will increase, and your knowledge of nature will improve. I am at your service."
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: "Excellent introduction, I make no pretence to scholarship, but I enjoy conversing with educated men. Kind of you to be so thoughtful of us." Turning to the grey-haired gentleman, he continued: "A name does not represent much of the individual, but without it we never get thoroughly acquainted. It is a sort of a telephonic connection which puts in communication soul with soul. In the absence of it everything is speculative."
speaker: Mr. Sprocton
addressee: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D. and Jones

utterance:
"I cannot agree with you, in that a name does not represent much of the individual. I have never been.
able to bring myself to acknowledge the sentiment expressed by England's greatest poet, in 'What's in a name?' Gentlemen, there is much in a name.
It is either a great blessing or a great curse. It makes us or breaks us."
speaker: Jones

utterance: "That's true, I know it's true, I've had experience. I put my name on twenty thousand dollars worth of paper for friends, and it broke me."
speaker: a Chicagoan

utterance: "I beg your pardon, I did not understand that you told us your name."
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance: "Oh, I am Jones, plain Jones from Boston, said he. If this smoking-room does not turn out to be an insane asylum, I am a false prophet."
speaker: Jones

utterance: "Jones! Yes, his name was John Jones and he came from Boston. He was a butcher on Lake Street, Chicago. Any relation of yours?"
speaker: a Chicagoan

utterance:
"My friend, I often return thanks to my Maker for His goodness to me, but if there is one thing for which I pour out my gratitude more fervently than for any other, it is that I'm not related to all the Joneses of America.
And a second cause for gratitude is that none of my relatives live in Chicago, as my family sympathies are strong."
speaker: Jones

utterance: "Eh! Ah! Oh! I see,"
speaker: a Chicagoan

utterance: "He is not your relative. I didn't know but he might be, both coming from such a small place as Boston."
speaker: a Chicagoan

utterance: "Yes, Boston is a small place, numerically speaking, compared with Chicago, but numbers are only figurative. A thousand bushels of oats represent less value than three hundred bushels of wheat. The value of a figure depends upon what it stands for, and to estimate the importance of a city you must take into consideration something more than the number of its inhabitants."
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance: "Your remarks are particularly applicable, when the census taker can use no discretion in his enumeration between a man and a thing with a vacuum in its head."
speaker: Jones

utterance:
"Oh, I beg your pardon, My name is Snubbins, Josiah Snubbins. I come from Chicago.
Everybody knows of Chicago. Most wonderful place in the world. More pigs killed there "
speaker: Snubbins

utterance: "Excuse me,"
speaker: Jones

utterance: "Please do not burden us with the wonders of Chicago. I have heard Chicagoans talk on their favorite theme before, and while the subject matter may be most interesting to the relator, I assure you it requires more good nature and generosity than intelligence to enable an outsider to appreciate it."
speaker: Jones

utterance: "Eh! Ah! Oh! I see! You know about Chicago! Wonderful place, wonderful place!"
speaker: Snubbins

utterance:
"That remark about conceit, suggests to my mind the query, 'What is conceit?' Certainly a great question, but one I am able to answer.
Speaking from a medical point of view it is one of a class of diseases; call them moral diseases if you wish, as you will the better understand it. If I were conversing with learned men of my profession I should classify them under the title Manie sans délire of Pinel, or, I might use some of the shorter terms, as Moralisches irresein, Folie raisonnante or Folie lucide, but when conversing with laymen I am always careful to confine myself to the commoner forms of expression, even though they do grate harshly upon my trained tympanum, as I consider it bad taste and indicative of sham to talk over the heads of one's listeners. This moral disease of conceit has a ravenous appetite. It devours everything palatable and rejects everything that is not. In studying the laws of human economy, as it becomes all learned physicians to do, and I am proud to say that I belong to that class and have expended much thought and original research upon these matters, we find if there be any weakness, be it physical or mental, or, speaking more scientifically, corporal or psychical,—as I have said I prefer using common terms in conversation with the laity,—all development is along that line, and when the weakness is psychical one becomes a unipersonalist, which when stripped of its religious application means a person with one idea. Excuse the term, but having explained it, I believe I am pardonable. That one idea may be ego, which is the Latin for I; excuse the term; in other words, the personification of conceit and self-glorification."
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: "I must admit, that your statement is very logical."
speaker: Jones

utterance: "Some speakers give force to their argument by an authoritative manner, others by their great knowledge of the subject, but you have been more cogent in your remarks than either, for they picture the speaker as the incarnate example of the principle he puts forth."
speaker: Jones

utterance: "Sir, my intelligence tells me, and all my nobler instincts confirm the opinion, that you have insulted me."
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: "My friend, control yourself, or you will force us to believe you are not acquainted with the code. A smokingroom has a license of which the cigar is a certificate. No one should feel hurt at anything that is said. The aroma of a cigar is the outwork and defence against bad manners and caustic thrusts. All rashness of temper should be exhaled with the smoke. Every one should wear a cheerful countenance, which pleases friends by its good nature and exasperates enemies by its serenity, and which is demanded in smoking-room etiquette."
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance:
"I know no code, neither do I intend to know anythat permits a man to insult me. My dignity has been assailed. It has been trampled upon.
It has been pierced."
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: "Mein frient, don't carry it so near de survace. It's pad."
speaker: a short, squattybuilt, middle-aged man

utterance: "What do you mean? I believe, sir, you are insinuating. Speak out and say what you mean."
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: "Don't carry dat ding you call dignity so near de survace, It makes fools of peebles. Ve all haf it but de vise man keeps it hid avay, und dot's vat makes him vise."
speaker: a short, squattybuilt, middle-aged man

utterance: "Is that German or American philosophy ?"
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance: "Dot is de philosophy of a man who knows de vorld is joost right, und ven peebles haf droubles mit it, it's 'cause dey see grooked. It vould be joost as easy to agree as disagree, if it vas not for dat ding called dignity, und vot is dignity? I don't know. Vot he say is dignity, (with a wave of the hand toward the Doctor) I say is vat is called gall, cheek und prass. In Cherman dey be different, but in America dey be all de same."
speaker: a short, squattybuilt, middle-aged man

utterance:
"I expected when I started on this trip, to be the recipient of some rudeness, but I did not expect to be insulted and then have it rubbed in.
Yes, sir, rubbed in, not an elegant expression but an emphatic one, by another insult on top of it. We in Texas settle insults according to rules of honor. My seconds will meet yours, and if you fail to respond you must take the consequences."
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance:
"Vot did I say, vot did I tell yous ? Didn't I say so? His dignity, with a wave of the hand toward the Doctor, "vants old pom-pom-pomposity," with a nod toward Jones, which caused that gentleman to open his grey eyes very wide, "to dake back vat he say ven he dolt de druth.
Jones relapsed and allowed his eyelids to resume their normal easy position. calls dat dignity. I calls it prass. vants me to stand up und be shot. it dignity. I calls it gall. Und if I don't vant to stand up und be shot, he say I must dake de consefences. I s'pose he vill k
speaker: a short, squattybuilt, middle-aged man
addressee: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D. and Jones

utterance:
"Holt on! Holt on! I say, sthop," Don't you say it, for it gif me de shifers. It joost makes a hot streak run up my pack alretty und den a colt von. I von't hear any more. It trives me most grazy. I dought dat nonsense you peen dalking vas getting near it, for von has joost so much sense as de oder.
Dat is your prag und your philosophy. Der differents is de prag show us how pig a fool you tink ve be, und de philosophy how pig a fool you be.
speaker: Schweneger

utterance:
"Gentlemen, you must remember that an uncultured mind is simply a mass of incongruities in its nudity. It should be handled with kindness and guided with magnanimity.
Excuse the term, it means elevation of the mind and dignity of the soul, and I am proud to say that I, being magnanimous myself, am able to treat this poor, ignorant man magnanimously. This, however, brings to my mind the magnanimous side of human nature, a subject on which I feel particularly well qualified to speak."
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: "I beg your pardon, As you have studied this subject so thoroughly, I fear you will exhaust it, and there will be nothing more to be said. I should like to suggest that others of the party be allowed to give their opinions first, and then you may, by summing up, point out our errors and set us straight.'
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance: "As you please, It's an excellent idea, for by knowing your own views I will be the more able to correct false impressions and lead you to see the truth."
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: "Mr. Jones, your hairs being most deserving of veneration, yours is the privilege of speaking first. What elements in human nature are evidences of the greatest magnanimity?"
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance: "True magnanimity, is automatic principle.”
speaker: Jones

utterance: "To hear such gems of truth, spoken by a man in the common walks of life is to us, dwelling in the exalted realms of social ethics, as food to our souls."
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: "Permit me to congratulate you, You have accomplished a great feat, for if your observation be correct, and I fully agree with it, you have certainly overcome the laws of gravi tation and are at this moment suspended in space."
speaker: Jones

utterance: "Dot be nodings strange, vot is a palloon? It be only a gas pag."
speaker: Schweneger

utterance: "Come to order, gentlemen, This constant wrangling is degrading. The smoking-room is the place of all others where good feeling should prevail, where every discussion should be most amicable, but we are degenerating into low comedy, where a mixture of spite and overdrawn merriment is intended to pass as humor. We are all pulling at a tangled skein. Gentlemen, please remember my ruling, Hereafter each man shall finish his remarks without interruption. Mr. Jones, will you please proceed with your observations on magnanimity?"
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance: "As I was observing, when interrupted, true magnanimity is automatic principle. What is automatic principle? It is a voluntary movement, a willing movement of a man's soul toward a noble act without stopping to say, 'This is a generous deed. All the world will look upon me as a benefactor.' If he thinks at all, he surely says, 'This is one little unit that I may add to a great work,' and he feels pleasure in having added the unit instead of regarding himself as a hero for having performed a great deed. A great act that is to be paraded before the world is doubtful magnanimity, for if one does not count up profit and loss and strike a balance, he knows the public will. The truly magnanimous man belongs to the rank and file of those to whom he shows his magnanimity, for patronizing of those beneath one is in the nature of pseudo-charity, rather than that of magnanimity. Our besetting sin is seeing magnanimity in proportion to its greatness, and not in proportion to the principle governing the act."
speaker: Jones

utterance:
"Your ideas are excellent, but I object to your specifications.
They are slightly anarchistic. You bar the possibility of a great public benefactor. There is no class of people that has the monopoly of being in the right, or of having all the right of principle, except campaign orators. I see no reason why a man giving a million dollars to build a hospital may not give it according to your principle of magnanimity, even though the world does strike a balance in his favor.
He is not to blame for that, but according to your specification magnanimity is not his.
But excuse me, gentlemen, I am monopolizing the time that belongs to you. Come, Mr.
Tapnagle, we have not heard much from you.
Give us your views on magnanimity."
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance: "A magnanimous man is true to his friends, loyal to his country and charitable to his enemies."
speaker: Tapnagle

utterance: "Excellent, a very terse, well-worded definition."
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance: "Well, Mr. Snubbins, what are your ideas of magnanimity ?"
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance:
"I don't know, Mr. Sprocton, as I have anything to offer on the subject.
It seems to me it would be very magnanimous for a man to pay his own debts, instead of leaving them for his endorser to pay. I would like to inspire one man with that sort of magnanimity, as I would be twenty thousand dollars better off. Oh, what a fool I was to sign those notes!"
speaker: Snubbins

utterance: "What's a German's idea of magnanimity ?"
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance:
"De Cherman's idea are not like de oders, You all seem to dink a man must do someding to be magnamous.
I dink a man may pe magnamous for doing nodings. De most magnamous ding a man efer do vas to mind his own pizness. De next most magnamous ding is to own your own faults und not dry to put dem off on 1 75 somepody else."
speaker: Schweneger

utterance: "And impressions have to germinate a long time, before they become convictions."
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "My recently formed opinion is, that the most magnanimous thing a man can do is to leave one undisturbed in his own conceit."
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "I shall have to handle that roughly, for I cannot compromise my principles with any such sordid vice as conceit. It is an indication of a weak intellect and ignorance combined, and to eradicate it is the duty of those more fortunate and learned. This is my principle, and no matter how disagreeable it may be, I never shirk my duty."
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: "Upon my word, Doctor, I believe you are right, and I shall take the first opportunity to follow your example. But regarding my settled convictions of magnanimity, I believe there is no such a thing as genuine magnanimity. The nearest one comes to it is to not hate more than he loves, nor to be more energetic in revenge than in friendship. Mr. Jones' definitions prove just the opposite of what he claims for them. What + 77 were they? A voluntary movement of a man's soul toward a noble deed, and also that he must feel the joy of having done a good deed, and not the elevation of a hero. I fail to see where the magnanimity comes in when a man is voluntarily drawn toward the performance of an act and feels a joy in performing it. That I would call selfishness. Everybody is selfish. So long as you are of use to one he will be magnanimous, so to speak, but if in his mind you have been a damage to him, magnanimity goes to the wind. I will cite as an illustration a case in which the Doctor can bear me out. He treats a child that is very sick. It gets well. The parents are grateful. They are magnanimous, you say, in their praise. Pay their bills promptly. Show their appreciation with bouquets, dressing sacques, slippers, etc. But another child is taken sick and dies. The Doctor has fought for the child's life as hard or even harder than for that of the one he saved, but where is the magnanimity? No praise, no prompt payment of bills, no bouquets, no dressing sacques, 88 no slippers, and nine to one they will say the Doctor killed the child."
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "You are mistaken, entirely so, so far as your remarks apply personally to me. I can imagine that parents might feel that way at the death of a child under the care of a physician having a limited knowledge, and consequently of limited resources, but not so when they know the doctor has done all that is in the power of man to do. Therefore, I never have such experiences. A few weeks ago I treated a woman, and although I did all that was possible to do for her, she died, and so much confidence did her son still have in me, in less than thirty minutes he was in my office to ask me to prescribe for his mother-in-law."
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: "Did the mother-inlaw die?"
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance: "No, sir, she made a rapid recovery."
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: "Poor disappointed beggar."
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance:
"Doctor, you will have to resume this discussion at the next session.
The meeting is adjourned."
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance: "Joost vot I say, ven a man dry to pass a fool for vot you call genus, he have to bay de discount."
speaker: Schweneger

utterance: "A maxim, no doubt, but quite incomprehensible to me. I don't understand its application."
speaker: Tapnagle

utterance:
"Vell, if you joost go in de schmokingroom, you haf an example. De Doctor is in vot you call, I s'pose, de slumps.
I say he peen sold but not baid for."
speaker: Schweneger

utterance: "This is a terror, a perfect terror, We can never survive it."
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "You don't mean there is any danger? The Captain says it's only a local storm, and that we are rapidly running out of it."
speaker: Tapnagle

utterance: "Ah! he said that because he wants us to die easy. He has no hope, no hope."
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "You may be frightened without cause, for the storm is nothing like as bad to-day as yesterday."
speaker: Tapnagle

utterance: "Oh, you don't understand, We might weather it if the machinery remained intact, but it is expected to go all to pieces every minute. The terrible storm we have had for two days has caused it to weaken, and the engineers say it can't hold together more than another hour or two at most, and then what?"
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "Every time we go around, we get deeper and deeper into the trough of the sea, until the engulfing waves clash together 87 over our heads. Then there will be one mighty splash; a spray will be sent a thousand feet in all directions, and the sea will descend upon us and then-well, another mysterious disappearance in mid-ocean."
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "You are a set of cowards,"
speaker: Tapnagle

utterance:
"Take care, Mr. Tapnagle, please be more circumspect in your remarks.
We are no cowards, are we, Doctor?"
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "Cowards! Your youth protects you from your rashness. But beware! I warn you not to repeat language that does violence to the feelings of gentlemen."
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: "You see, the Doctor and I pride ourselves on our courage, but we are in a position similar to that of Napoleon in Russia, and whoever accused Napoleon of being a coward? We are not afraid of man, but who can battle against the Omnipotent Ruler of the elements? We only thirst for an opportunity to pierce a man through who has insulted our dignity. Fighting a band of savages with a sword in one hand and a sabre in another, would be only a pastime. Hey, Doctor?"
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "Indeed it would,"
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance:
"Oh, but for the opportunity to charge on an enemy, The clash of steel, the enemy vanquished, the victory won! What leaders of men we would make! How our courage would inspire them on! An army of five thousand men would, under our leadership, be equal to ten thousand.
Sheridan's ride would be forgotten in the magnificence of our victories."
speaker: O'Connell

utterance:
"There comes another, Oh, and she's a big one. She is coming right at us. Look at her! Look at her !
She'll swamp us."
speaker: O'Connell

utterance:
"Oh, and faith she We are lost! We is coming right over us.
are lost!"
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "We are climbing her! We are climbing her!"
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "We are over her! We are saved, thank God!"
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "Faith, but I believe here comes another, Sure and it's the biggest one yet."
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "C-ca-ca-can't y-y-you p-p-pray?"
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: "Pray? Why, man, I am praying all the time.'
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "Yes, here she comes, Oh, she's a big one."
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "Doctor, you pray."
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "I—I—I—c-ca-can't,"
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance:
"See here, you must pray. You are a man of great learning, of great intellect, of great resources, of great argumentative power, of great persuasion, and of great courage. It is your duty to stand by us less fortunate in such a time of danger. You must tell the Lord a few things and make Him believe them.
You can do it."
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "Of course I can,"
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: "You tell him this, that we are taking this trip for the glory of God and for penance, and we will have angels' wings growing on us twenty feet long before we reach the other side. Be quick about it though, or you may be too late."
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "For here comes a monster. It's right over us. We are swamped! We are swamped!"
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: "What on earth are you trying to do, Doctor? What kind of a performance do you call it, anyway?"
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance: "What's the matter here?"
speaker: Mr. Sprocton

utterance: "Vot's de matter? O'Connell has got de Doctor in a pottle, und got his dhumb vere de cork vants to go."
speaker: Schweneger

utterance: "The fact is unalterable, my fellow companions, it makes me tremble to relate that we are in a perilous position. A terrible storm is upon us and the machinery is about to break down,"
speaker: O'Connell

utterance:
Remember, Tapnagle, that you agreed to read some poetry for me to-day.
I think we had better convene about ten A. M.
If you see the other companions, mention the time to them, except Jones. He seems to enjoy coming in a little late, in the midst of our discussions, and I should dislike to take that pleasure from him. I will see that he is there when he is needed. I shall demonstrate, I think to the satisfaction of all, the truth of the saying, 'The pen is mightier than the sword.'
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Vot is he going to do?
speaker: Schweneger

utterance: Don't know, I am repeating his own words.
speaker: Tapnagle

utterance: Don't know?
speaker: Schweneger

utterance: Vell, I can dell you he is going to get up a row mit dat empty headed Chicagoan und de Doctor.
speaker: Schweneger

utterance:
I don't understand how you figure that,
said I, "Snubbins is a very peaceable fellow and I don't see how a row between them would prove the pen is mightier than the sword.
speaker: Tapnagle

utterance: You don't understand, said he, somewhat excitedly. If Snubbins dhrashes de Doctor von't dat broof it? Ain't Texas de blace of der sword? Efery man dere has vun sticking avay somevhere, ready to zip it drough you, und ain't Chicago de city of pens? Dere be more pig-bens dere dan any ober blace in de vorld. Vot's blainer dan dot?
speaker: Schweneger

utterance: Gentlemen, you have no doubt often heard it remarked that the truth should not always be spoken. Dr. Hobbs here, a philosopher of distinction, will admit, I think, that the truth must often be suppressed, and there are also times when diplomacy demands that it shall even be controverted.
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Your judgment does you credit. I will never agree to any restriction of the liberty of the press, for it unmasks the false pretenses of the wicked and exposes dishonesty and sham.
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance:
But Doctor, take this case for instance. A man has been indiscreet; has lied considerably; not to harm any one, but simply for self-gratification. All the pleasure some people get in this life is in hearing their own lies, and judging from the way they indulge in it, I imagine it must be delightful. Now, Doctor, I want to ask you a plain question and I want a plain answer.
With such a case as this, where every one knows the fellow has been bragging and lying, but without harm to any one except himself, do you think a paper should publish an article showing him up to the world, blackening his name and ruining his character ?
speaker: O'Connell

utterance:
You have asked a plain question, and you shall have a plain answer.
I say emphatically, yes. You should understand, knowing me as you ought to by this time, knowing my depth of sincerity, my generosity of nature, my breadth of character, my mastery of philosophy, and my experience in original research, that not an atom of my body,-excuse the term, gentlemen (to the visitors), an atom is the smallest particle of matter that can exist,-could compromise with anything savoring of braggadocio or lying.
No man of sense will brag, no man of character will lie. While a man without sense may be forgiven, a man without character should be exposed, and the press is justified in exposing such a person to the world. I even go farther and say it is the duty of the press to expose such rascals.
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: I am delighted that you hold such opinions, for you will be better able to bear the shock you are about to receive, and to forgive the author of the poem we will now read you. I must admit that I feared you would kill him on the spot, but now, knowing your sentiments on the subject, I see you will thank him for fulfilling his duty to mankind. This poem refers to you, Doctor, and our mutual friend, Mr. Tapnagle, has agreed to read the verses, while I have reserved to myself the disagreeable duty of reading the choruses which come in after the verses.
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Assuredly, no one can say aught against me as a man, a gentleman and a scholar.
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: That depends.
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Chorus
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Hear that, The Texas Doctor;' certainly no mistaking for whom that is intended. Proceed, Mr. Tapnagle.
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Chorus
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Chorus
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: I request, I claim my right as a gentleman, I demand, to know the author of that poem. I'll kill him as I would a rat. He shall not escape me. I'll hound him to the ends of the earth, coward and villain that he is. Oh, but let me know his name that I may challenge him on the spot!
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: Be calm, be calm, my dear Doctor, sit down and let me tell you all about it. Now this one, with two other poems which we will read immediately, has been written by a certain man aboard this ship who is passing himself off as a gentleman traveling for the pleasure it affords, but who is in reality a newspaper reporter traveling for a press association. These poems are placed in the middle of a long article about you, which sets forth among other things: First, you are so ignorant, that you believe yourself educated; second, you are such a chronic, habitual prevaricator that you believe your own lies; third, you are such a coward that you resort to all kinds of buffoonery to make people believe you are brave; fourth, you are such a fool that you believe yourself wise. Now, while we all know that these representations are the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth, we were disposed to assist you, for as I said a few moments ago, even the truth should not always be spoken, and you will also remember I deprecated the license of the press, but you disagreed with me on that point, so I do not see that we can be of any assistance to you, as according to your own views, you will demand • that this article be published, for you must admit that it sets forth the truth, as we all know it does.
speaker: O'Connell

utterance:
I have changed my mind on that, nervously. Yes, I have changed my mind. There is no doubt about it, Mr.
O'Connell, I have changed my mind. Yes, truly, I wish you to believe it, for I am telling the truth now, I have changed my mind.
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance:
Very well, we believe you and will see what can be done to assist you, but first let's have the other poems. Mr.
Tapnagle will read the second.
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: The title of this poem, said I, is "The Ignoramus."
speaker: Tapnagle

utterance: The Ignoramus,
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Think of it. Just think of it.
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Chorus
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Chorus
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Horrible, horrible
speaker: O'Connell

utterance:
While we must all admit that it is the truth, it is none the less horrible.
Gentlemen, do you understand the seriousness of this affair? An article of this character published in thousands of papers throughout the country, even in the papers of his own village, would ruin him. It would annihilate his character. It would take away his practice. It would rob him of his support, as no one would employ him. Undoubtedly many of his patients have recognized the truth of these assertions, as it does not require any great insight into human nature, so plainly visible are they, but the exact condition of affairs has been ill defined in their minds.
They haven't realized the risk they have been taking in employing such a scapegrace, but they will when they read this article, which sets forth in plain prose the facts, and then illuminates those facts with the radiance of poetic song, making the ridicule more ridiculous, the disgrace more degrading, the crime more criminal, the danger more dangerous.
As one couplet sets forth: 666 Although 'tis hazardous for you to smoke In powder magazines, they may not go off; And loaded guns folks point at you in joke, Your head-if you are lucky-may not blow off; But if you let a Texas Doctor pill you, Make your will first; for it's a cinch he'll kill you.'
Oh, the power of poetry! I tell you, gentlemen, this must not be published.
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: No, no, no, it must not be published,
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance:
But let's have the third and last poem,
said O'Connell.
Mr. Tapnagle, will you please read it?
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: It is entitled 'The Falstaffian Doctor,'
speaker: Tapnagle

utterance: Listen, said O'Connell, as I read. The Falstaffian Doctor;' no mistaking the identity.
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Chorus
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Chorus
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Yes, let's stop it.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Hang the reporter,
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Now, Doctor, while we all know you have been lying and bragging and bluffing and blowing, we are going to save you all the same; so brace up.
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Now, Doctor, O'Connell went on, while we all know that this reporter has written the truth, we believe he has taken an unwarranted liberty, and should be severely chastised, and we propose to give you that opportunity right here in this room.
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Oh, but mention his name! My dignity, my honor must be avenged! Mention his name, O'Connell just his name, and I will hurl a challenge at him like a thunderbolt.
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: Be calm, Doctor, remember it behooves us as gentlemen to do things in a calm, dignified manner. Rashness does not become a gentleman, and you must remember also that the reporter has the truth on his side.
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Sir, I have no need of your advice as to what is becoming a gentleman. I was born a gentleman, I was reared a gentleman, I was educated a gentleman, and I know what is be149 coming a gentleman, without being instructed by any one, and as a gentleman I demand that reporter's name.
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: Certainly, we all know you are a gentleman, but when a man gets hasty he is apt to forget himself. But the name of the reporter; who is the man who comes into this smoking-room late, picks out the time when you are engaged in a learned philosophical discussion, and interrupts you with an insulting remark? What's his name but Jones?
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: I knew it, I knew it all the time. Let me but cast my eyes on him and I will hurl a challenge at him.
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: Lay hold of him. He will do damage if you don't. Remember he is a bold, rash man.
speaker: O'Connell

utterance:
Who is the man who sits day after day in this room, chatting, and when you kindly consent to instruct us ignorant fellows in some learned problem, turns around, crosses his legs and rests his elbow on the arm of the chair?
What's his name but Jones?
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Oh, that man Jones,
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: Let me go; let me find him and I will challenge him on the spot.
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance:
Hold him fast. He has murder in his eye. I can see it flashing. Remember he is a desperate character.
Who is the man, he went on, who after you had generously excused him from an affair of honor, and had given him an opportunity to justify himself in a debate, replied that he objected to putting himself on your level as it would necessitate getting down on all fours and braying? What's his name but Jones ?
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Here comes Jones. Remember, Doctor, you have two demands. First, that he shall deliver to you at once, and in the presence of all here, the article, and second, that he shall give you satisfaction in a duel. Of course your honor would demand the duel, but don't fail to get the manuscript.
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Mr. Jones, I demand that article I demand that article-I say, I demand that article!
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: Damn it, man, are you deaf? I demand that article, and I also challenge you to an affair of honor.
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance:
Oh, it is the same old story.
I thought at first there was something really new.
speaker: Jones

utterance: I say I demand that article, yelled the frantic Doctor, who had been loosened by his captors, and having full liberty of his arms, swung them at full length over his head, as well as over the heads of the others. I demand that article, he repeated, that you have written about me. You shall never publish it, even if I have to kill you as a cowardly cur to prevent it.
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: I have no article, replied Jones, with a 153 puzzled expression. I don't know what you mean.
speaker: Jones

utterance:
You can't put me off with a denial, exclaimed the enraged Doctor. I know what you have got. I know all about it. I've even heard the poetry that is in the middle of it.
I'll have that article if I die for it, and I'll have satisfaction from you if I have to do murder.
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: I have told you, said Jones, emphatically, I have no article, at the same time sitting down, assuming his favorite position, crossing his legs and resting his elbow on the arm of the chair.
speaker: Jones

utterance: We all know, said he, seriously, that the doctor has been lying, but don't ruin him. It's his bread and butter. Give him the article.
speaker: O'Connell

utterance: Give him the article. Give him the article.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Give him the article.
speaker: Tapnagle

utterance: Yes, I accept your challenge, even if you are a lunatic, and I'll fight you right here.
speaker: Jones

utterance: Doctor Hobbs, you have challenged me to a duel. I believe, according to the rules governing such affairs of dishonor, the privilege of selecting the time, place and implements of war is mine.
speaker: Jones

utterance: All gentlemen, replied the Doctor, gravely, for he was now in a grave mood, leave that to seconds.
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: Well, I am no gentleman, cried Jones, even more angrily than before. I make no pretension to being a gentleman and consequently I am not governed by a gentleman's code. I will decide the matter myself. I choose this smoking-room as the place; time, the present, and the weapons that God has given us. Strip yourself and prepare for action.
speaker: Jones

utterance:
I see, said he, finally, I have made a mistake in taking this man for what he is not.
I don't wish the gentlemen here to believe that I would be guilty of knowingly challenging a man beneath me, for certainly no one knows better than I that a gentleman of my standing cannot, without lowering himself in the estimation of other gentlemen, fight a duel with a man who has not only acknowledged that he is no gentleman, but has proved it by his brutal methods. I am, therefore, obliged to call this affair off.
speaker: Pemberton Hobbs, M. D.

utterance: You shall not call it off, shouted Jones, rolling his shirt sleeves still higher and exhibiting his wondrously developed biceps and triceps, until I throttle th
speaker: Jones
